scenario:
Spotify Technology and Netflix are expected to report solid revenue growth in 2025, with both companies likely to build upon their leadership positions in their respective markets. Analysts have reached a bullish consensus on both stocks, with 22 out of 38 analysts covering Spotify and 25 out of 55 analysts covering Netflix assigning the highest possible buy rating.

Spotify has a global market share of 31.7% in the music streaming business, and it invests heavily in technologies like artificial intelligence to keep users engaged. The company is on track to deliver a record $16 billion in revenue for 2024, a 17% jump from 2023, and Wall Street's consensus forecast suggests its annual revenue could reach another record of $18.4 billion in 2025.

However, Spotify's stock is considered a little expensive, trading at a price-to-sales (P/S) ratio of 5.8, which is a 52% premium to its average since the company went public in 2018. Analysts have an average price target of $495 for Spotify stock over the next 12 months, implying a gain of just 6% from where it trades as of this writing.

Netflix is the world's largest streaming platform for movies and TV shows, with 282.7 million paying subscribers at the end of the third quarter of 2024. The company launched an advertising-supported tier at the end of 2022, which has proven extremely popular, and it invested heavily in live programming during 2024. Netflix will report results for the final quarter of 2024 on Jan. 21, and according to Wall Street's consensus forecast, the company is on track to generate a record $38.9 billion in revenue for the year.

However, Netflix's stock is also considered expensive, trading at a price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 49.8, which is significantly more expensive than the Nasdaq-100 technology index. Analysts have an average price target of $850.19 for Netflix stock, which is below where it's trading as of this writing, implying no upside over the next 12 months.
